Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Systematic Analysis of the Photodegradation of Pesticides on Heterogeneous Surfaces: The Photolysis of Imidazolinone Herbicides on Two Midwest Crops
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor Amanda Nienow from Gustavus Adolphus College who will explore the heterogeneous chemistry of pesticides sorbed to the crop/plant surfaces to which they are applied with a focus on the photolysis mechanisms and photoproducts formed when one class of pesticides, the imidazaolinone herbicides, is applied to plants. The photochemistry of some imidazolinone herbicides has been examined in aqueous systems but not on plant surfaces; this examination will provide insight into the photodegradation mechanisms and photoproducts of these herbicides at crop surfaces, thereby enhancing current understanding of the environmental chemistry of the imidazolinone herbicides. In addition, the knowledge gained from this work will inform reconnaissance missions for measurement of organic pollutants in the environment, provide a molecular understanding of the chemistry occurring at the plant surface, and potentially influence regulation of pesticide application.

This project will provide a more realistic picture of the environmental fate of pesticides by examining photolysis of pesticides sorbed to cuticular wax and plant foliage. The research has implications for environmental modeling and pesticide regulation. In addition, the methods and protocols developed under this project will be a model for studying a wide range of pesticides or other environmentally relevant organic molecules, and may be extended to study the photochemistry of organic molecules on other surfaces, (e.g., urban buildings). The undergraduates will participate in all aspects of this interdisciplinary project and will gain experience in a wide range of fields including spectroscopy, chromatography, microscopy, and statistical data analysis. The students' experiences will improve their ability to plan, analyze, synthesize and communicate scientific results. In addition, they will gain experience presenting at national meetings and co-authoring peer reviewed journal articles. All of these experiences will position them well for future graduate studies or professional careers. The principal investigator is a faculty member early in her career, so this project will benefit her by supporting foundational research and establishment of a sustainable research program. The results will be disseminated through publications and presentations at scientific conferences. Aspects of the project will also be used to enhance the Chemistry Department's established community outreach into local elementary schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When herbicides are applied to fields, several things can happen. The herbicide can be taken up by plants within the field, often causing them harm; the herbicide can dissolve in water and run-off the fields into nearby waterways; and the herbicide can degrade due to microorganisms, chemical reactions, or photochemical degradation due to the energy from the sun. The overarching objective of this research was to examine the photochemistry a class of herbicides, the imidazolinones, undergoes when in water, deposited on epicuticlar wax (the waxy layer of a leaf), and on corn and soybean leaves. The photochemistry in water was examined under circumstances modeling run-off of the herbicides from the fields into waterways. Corn and soybeans waxes and plant surfaces were selected because of the prevalence of these crops in the Midwest and because the imidazolinone herbicides are used on these crops.  

The photodegradation of the imidazolinone herbicides imazamox, imazapic, imazaquin, and imazamethabenzmethyl has been investigated in phosphate-buffered solutions and buffered solutions containing natural organic matter (NOM), a model for river water. All photodegradation rate constants increased with pH and plateaued after pH 5.2 suggesting that the degradation of these compounds will be faster near-neutral, natural waters as compared to acidic water. All imidzaolinones degraded more quickly under 253.7 nm lamps as compared to degradation under 310 nm lamps showing that the energy of light is an important parameter. In solutions with NOM, photodegradation reaction rate constants decreased. This was determined to be due to the effect of light screening (i.e., the NOM is blocking light from reaching the herbicides for reaction). Formulas for the proposed photoproducts for imazethapyr, imazamox, imazapic, and imazaquin in pH 7 phosphate buffers were identified. 

The photodegradation rate of the herbicide imazethapyr on epicuticular waxes of soybean and corn plants was investigated. Plant age, relative humidity, temperature, and number of light banks were varied during plant growth, analyzed statistically, and examined to determine if these factors had an effect on the photodegradation of imazethapyr. Plant age, the interaction between plant age and light, and a quadratic dependence on temperature were all determined to have a significant impact on the photodegradation rate of imazethapyr on the epicuticular waxes of soybean plants. As for the photodegradation rate on the epicuticular waxes of corn plants, the number of light banks used during growing and temperature were significant factors. 

The research has implications for environmental modeling and pesticide regulation –the chemical structures of the photodegradation products will suggest answers to questions such as “Are the photochemically transformed pesticides (i.e. photodegradation products) more soluble?”, “Are the photochemically transformed pesticides more biologically active?”, and “Are the photochemically transformed pesticides more mobile?” In addition, the methods and protocols developed under the project will be a model for studying a wide range of pesticides or other environmentally relevant organic molecules, and may be extended to study the chemistry of organic molecules sorbed to other surfaces, such as the windows of urban buildings.  In addition, toxicologists might be interested in studying the toxicology of the photoproducts formed during photolysis, especially if those photoproducts differ between the experiments in aqueous solution and experiments on waxes. 

The results of this project were published in 2 papers, reported as 5 presentations at national meetings of American Chemical Society, international conferneces, and Gordon Research conferences, and presented as 2 invited lectures. A collaboration with researchers at the University of Blaise Pascal in Clermont-Ferrand, France was also established. 

This project supported research for college students; four students were paid directly by this grant and others were indirectly impacted by the project by working alongside the paid students in the lab or by learning about this science from Dr. Nienow in classes and seminars. The students working directly under the grant gained excellent training in all areas of science from project proposals to writing up the data for publication. The students also had the chance to work with international collaborators, present their work at national meetings, and publish their first journal articles. Two of these students are now in graduate school and two are pursuing medical school. 

Finally, this project supported the Gustavus Adolphus Chemistry Club through outreach events in rural Minnesota. Each year, the club sponsors three chemistry events for elementary and preschool students in which the children come to campus to conduct experiments and watch demonstrations. These groups include the public school system's preschool with children from varied socioeconomic and racial/ethnic backgrounds, including many recent immigrants. It is our hope that we can inspire some of these students to be interested in science! 


Last Modified: 12/20/2016
Modified by: Amanda Nienow
